Title: Diving medicine
Content: Diving medicine also called undersea and hyperbaric medicine UHB is the diagnosis treatment and prevention of conditions caused by humans entering the undersea environment. Diving medical practitioners are also expected to be competent in the examination of divers and potential divers to determine fitness to dive. Diving medicine deals with medical research on issues of diving. Hyperbaric medicine is a corollary field associated with diving since recompression in a hyperbaric chamber is used as a treatment for two of the most significant divingrelated illnesses decompression sickness and arterial gas embolism. Diving medicine is a branch of occupational medicine and sports medicine and at first aid level an important part of diver education. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is the definitive treatment for most conditions of decompression illness. The administration of oxygen as a medical intervention is common in diving medicine both for first aid and for longer term. and definitive treatment where diving is involved. First aid oxygen administration at high concentration which is seldom contraindicated. Normobaric oxygen administration at the highest available concentration is frequently used as first aid for any diving injury. There is epidemiological support for its use from a statistical study of cases recorded in a long term database. Recompression treatment in a hyperbaric chamber was initially used as a lifesaving tool to treat decompression sickness in caisson workers and divers.  Hyperbaric oxygen treatment is generally preferred when effective as it is usually a more efficient and lower risk method of reducing symptoms of decompression illness. In some cases recompression to pressures where oxygen toxicity is unacceptable may be required to treat decompression sickness. First aid treatment of diving related disorders is part of the basic training for most recreational and professional divers. A recreational diver has the same duty of care to other divers as any ordinary member of the public and therefore there is no obligation to train recreational divers in first aid. First aid training is recommended by most if not all recreational diver training agencies. Recreational diving instructors and divemasters on the other hand are to a greater or lesser extent responsible for the safety of divers under their guidance. They are generally required to be trained and certified to some level of rescue and first aid competence. Professional divers are expected to act as standby divers for other members of the team. The duties of a standby diver include rescue attempts if the working diver gets into difficulties. Professional divers are generally required to be trained in rescue procedures appropriate for diving accidents. Diving supervisors have a similar duty of care and are responsible for operational planning and safety. They are also expected to manage emergency procedures including the first aid that may be required. The level of first aid training competence and registration varies and may be specified by state or national legislation. In South Africa registered commercial and scientific divers must hold current certification in first aid at the national Level 1 with additional training in oxygen administration for diving accidents. registered diving supervisors must hold Level 2 first aid certification.
